a) BS-2 (Bharat Stage 2) and BS-3 (Bharat Stage 3) are both emission standards set by the Indian government to regulate the amount of pollutants emitted by vehicles. BS-3 engines emit less pollutants than BS-2 engines due to the use of advanced emission control technologies such as improved fuel injection, better combustion and exhaust gas recirculation.

b) White smoke during start-up is usually caused by coolant or water entering the combustion chamber. This can be caused by a head gasket leak or a cracked engine block. To prevent this, the engine should be inspected for any leaks or damage before it is started.

c) DTSI (Digital Twin Spark Ignition) is a technology used in motorbikes that utilizes twin spark plugs to improve combustion efficiency and reduce emissions. The twin spark plugs ensure a more complete combustion of the fuel-air mixture, resulting in better fuel efficiency and reduced emissions.

d) A panhard rod, also known as a track bar, is a suspension component used in vehicles to prevent lateral movement of the axle during cornering. It is commonly used in solid axle suspension systems.

e) Calorific value is the amount of energy released per unit of fuel when it is burned. The calorific value of petrol is around 44.4 MJ/kg.

f) Anti-lock braking system (ABS) is a safety feature in vehicles that prevents the wheels from locking up during hard braking, which helps to maintain steering control and prevent skidding.

g) Air-fuel ratio is the ratio of air to fuel in the combustion chamber. If a spark plug deposits black soot, it may indicate a rich air-fuel mixture, meaning there is more fuel than air in the combustion chamber.

h) Firing order is the sequence in which the cylinders of an engine fire. The firing order of an opposed four-cylinder engine is typically 1-4-3-2.

i) The basic purpose of a four-wheel drive system is to provide power to all four wheels of a vehicle, improving traction and stability in low-traction conditions such as snow, mud, and off-road terrain.

j) Automobile tires are black in color due to the addition of carbon black, a reinforcing filler that improves the strength and durability of the tire. The black color also helps to dissipate heat generated by friction between the tire and the road.

a) What is difference between BS-2 and BS-3 engine?

Bharat Stage (BS) emission standards are set by the Indian government to regulate the amount of pollutants emitted by vehicles. The BS-3 standard is more stringent than the BS-2 standard.

BS-3 engines are designed to emit fewer pollutants than BS-2 engines. They achieve this by incorporating advanced emission control technologies such as improved fuel injection, better combustion and exhaust gas recirculation. BS-3 engines are typically more fuel-efficient than BS-2 engines, as they use cleaner fuel and burn it more efficiently.

BS-2 engines emit more pollutants than BS-3 engines. They use less advanced emission control technologies and therefore burn fuel less efficiently. BS-2 engines also use less clean fuel, resulting in higher emissions.

b) What is the reason for emitting the white exhaust smoke during start of the vehicle? how will you prevent this?

White smoke during start-up is usually caused by coolant or water entering the combustion chamber. This can be caused by a head gasket leak or a cracked engine block. The coolant or water then mixes with the fuel and air in the combustion chamber, resulting in white smoke coming out of the exhaust.

To prevent white smoke during start-up, the engine should be inspected for any leaks or damage before it is started. The head gasket and engine block should be checked for any cracks or signs of damage. If any damage is found, the engine should be repaired or replaced as necessary. Regular maintenance such as checking the coolant level and replacing the coolant at recommended intervals can also help prevent white smoke during start-up.

c) what is DTSI? why this technology is used in motor bikes?

Digital Twin Spark Ignition (DTSI) is a technology used in motorbikes that utilizes twin spark plugs to improve combustion efficiency and reduce emissions. The twin spark plugs ensure a more complete combustion of the fuel-air mixture, resulting in better fuel efficiency and reduced emissions.

In a conventional single-spark ignition system, a single spark plug is used to ignite the fuel-air mixture in the combustion chamber. With DTSI, two spark plugs are used, located at opposite ends of the combustion chamber. This ensures that the fuel-air mixture is ignited more quickly and more completely, resulting in better combustion efficiency and reduced emissions.

DTSI technology is used in motorbikes to improve performance and reduce emissions. It can help to improve fuel efficiency, increase power output, and reduce exhaust emissions.

d) What is pan hard rod or track bar?

A panhard rod, also known as a track bar, is a suspension component used in vehicles to prevent lateral movement of the axle during cornering. It is commonly used in solid axle suspension systems.

The panhard rod is a rigid bar that connects the axle to the chassis of the vehicle. It is mounted on one side of the vehicle and extends to the opposite side. During cornering, the panhard rod helps to keep the axle centered under the vehicle, reducing lateral movement and improving handling.

The panhard rod is an important component of a suspension system, as it helps to improve stability and handling during cornering. It is commonly used in off-road vehicles and other vehicles that are designed for high-performance driving.

e) What is the calorific value and what is the calorific value of petrol?

Calorific value is the amount of energy released per unit of fuel when it is burned. It is typically measured in units of joules per kilogram (J/kg) or megajoules per kilogram (MJ/kg).

The calorific value of petrol is around 44.4 MJ/kg. This means that when one kilogram of petrol is burned, it releases around 44.4 megajoules of energy.

a) De-Dion Drive

De-Dion drive is a type of rear suspension system that is commonly used in automobiles. It was first developed by the French engineer, Charles-Armand Trépardoux, in the 1890s. The De-Dion drive system is used to connect the rear wheels of a vehicle to the chassis or frame.

In a De-Dion drive system, a solid beam or tube is used to connect the two rear wheels to each other. The beam is then connected to the chassis or frame of the vehicle through a set of pivots or ball joints. This allows the wheels to move up and down independently of each other, while still maintaining a constant distance between them.

The De-Dion drive system provides several advantages over other types of rear suspension systems, including improved handling, stability, and ride comfort. It also helps to reduce the unsprung weight of the vehicle, which can improve its overall performance.

b) Double Declutching and Necessity of Free Play in Clutch Paddle Operation

Double declutching is a technique used in manual transmission vehicles to downshift the gears smoothly, without causing any damage to the transmission or engine. In this technique, the driver first releases the accelerator pedal and then presses the clutch pedal to disengage the clutch. The driver then shifts the transmission into neutral, releases the clutch pedal, and then presses the clutch pedal again to shift into a lower gear.

The purpose of double declutching is to match the speed of the engine with the speed of the transmission, ensuring a smooth and seamless shift. This is particularly important when downshifting, as the higher engine speed can cause the wheels to lock up and skid, leading to a loss of control.

Free play in the operation of the clutch pedal is necessary to ensure proper engagement and disengagement of the clutch. The free play refers to the amount of movement in the clutch pedal before it begins to engage the clutch. This allows the driver to fully disengage the clutch when shifting gears, and to smoothly engage the clutch when starting from a stop or shifting gears.

If there is not enough free play in the clutch pedal, the clutch may not fully disengage, causing the gears to grind and leading to premature wear on the clutch and transmission. If there is too much free play, the clutch may not engage fully, leading to slipping and reduced power transmission.
